answers.answer: I take it you mean high blood pressure?  You should go in to the ER to rule out the big things that can cause parasthesia, such as transient ischemic attacks, which can be a warning sign that you might have a full blown stroke.  See PM for more info about what can cause tingling.

HiWelcome to the MedHelp forum!Crestor that you are taking to lower the cholesterol is also known to cause peripheral neuropathies that could be causing the numbness. It could also be due to peripheral artery disease. The other possibility is that beyond a point your blood pressure really falls thus hampering circulation. Hence a 24 hour blood pressure monitoring should be done. Diabetes and hypothyroidism should be ruled out.  Do consult your doctor regarding these possibilities. Please let me know if there is any thing else and do keep me posted. Take care!

Some cholesterol medication can cause muscle weakness or pain. Talk to your doctor mayb he can try a different kind of medicine they are quite a few for cholesterol. Also the pain below the rib cage can be a number of things. I would also bring that up to the doctor.

question: Hey There,Sorry if i am in the wrong place. I am taking crestor right now for my high cholesterol and i do have blood pressure. For the last 2 weeks, whenever i lay around or don't do any movements, my arm goes numb within 4-8 seconds, same for my legs and feet. When i say numb i mean i feel a tingling sensation within my arm, hands, feet and legs. I do not know what it is so i would appreciate some help. Could it be bad blood circulation? I also have been having some pain below my rib cage, right where my liver is.Thanks
title: Body Numbmess
